ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1 hour
0. Did not spend any hours outside of the classroom on work.
I didn't spend any time outside of seminar.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Good
I find the seminars to be very interesting, and the pizza to be very tasty.

The course provide a broad perspective on the different types of work being done mainly in research with speakers that will appeal to a subset of individuals. I wish there was a way to organize the talks so that there is a theme or general topic for a few lectures before moving onto a different topic. Although research is the focus, I also wish there was more application of public health and research into practice as to realize what kind of job opportunities are available for those not continuing on with further education.

I really enjoyed the talks this semester. All in all I enjoyed the subjects more this semester than last semester but that might also be because my knowledge for infectious disease epidemiology has grown since first semester and therefore can be more engaged by the speakers.The speaker from Stanford was the best lecture of the year. I wish that lecture could have gone on for another two hours followed by a discussion at a local bar.
Interesting and keeps students up to date on current research which is useful
Borden your horizon in infectious disease control and development.
Excellent speakers. I will continue to come to the seminar next year even though it is not required anymore.

A great way to introduce students to various areas of research.Strengths: Glad that we are introduced to so many lecturers, concepts, etc. Like collaboration with CIRA. Really appreciate the generous lunch provided.Weaknesses: Material is often not catered to students. Lecturers covering advanced laboratory techniques may not be appropriate for students. Feels like these lectures are more geared toward faculty. Lectures some times run long. Perhaps we should schedule these lectures for 1 1/4 hours? Also, my biggest suggestion is to show students more career options for when they graduate with their MPH in EMD. I feel that some other divisions are inherently easier for students to understand where they will take their careers after graduation, but some, like EMD, are not so easy. Some students know they will apply for PhD programs, or medical school, but I feel that others may not know what to do with their degree. Perhaps presentations by professionals that are not research based are appropriate, such as hospital ID specialists, immunologists, etc.
The lectures were good this semester, they are typically diverse.
The speakers this semester, especially the one who spoke on network epidemiology and the one who spoke on the history of cholera, were excellent.
I really enjoyed the different seminar presentations in general. There were a few that did not seem to be targeted to specialists.
I think it is great.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Albert Ko  He was very good about opening the floor to students and encouraging students to ask questions.

Instructor: Albert Ko  Albert Ko made sure that the MPH students had a chance to ask their questions to the speakers before the PhD, post-docs, faculty and staff asked questions.The addition of salad to the seminar was also much appreciated.
Instructor: Albert Ko  He did a good job facilitating. I commend him this semester because he would always set a little time aside at the end of lecture for MPH students to ask questions.
Instructor: Albert Ko  He is listed as the instructor but does not really play an instructor role in seminar
Instructor: Albert Ko  Responsible asscessible , kind to students and thoughtful.
Instructor: Albert Ko  Funny. I wish I can fall asleep during seminars and still ask some profound questions in the end.
Instructor: Albert Ko  All the instructors provided decent introductions.
Instructor: Albert Ko  Because of the nature of the seminar, there was not much teaching that Dr. Ko did. He was an adequate host.
Instructor: Albert Ko  NA

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Highly recommend
It's required!

The seminar course is made available to allow students to listen to speakers from different aspects of public health research in microbial diseases and broaden their perspective into the types of work being done in the field.
Go, you are fed and will learn a lot, possibly even network with a few incoming speakers. I will try to go to as many as I can next semester.
Interesting, informative
Good chance to learn about cutting edge researches and boarded your horizon in infectious disease surveillance and control.
yes
A great way to hear about current research and concepts.
Informative and interesting!
This is a great way to learn about different topics within the field, to have access to a number of top experts in the field, and to be able to ask questions of these experts.

The seminar was good and had no work outside of the hour. There was always and interesting topic and lunch. I think there would be opportunities to meet the speakers on occasion. This could be really good to make connections in areas that interest you.
I very much enjoyed EMD Seminar. I think the seminars were very applicable to current research and merged nicely with subjects under study in the classroom.
